One of the main solutions proposed by John Maynard Keynes in "The General Theory of Employment, Interest, and Money" is for governments to use fiscal policy to stimulate aggregate demand during times of economic downturns. This can be achieved through government spending on public works projects, increasing transfer payments to individuals, and cutting taxes to increase disposable income.

Keynes also argued that monetary policy could be used to influence aggregate demand by manipulating interest rates and the money supply. He believed that central banks should lower interest rates to stimulate borrowing and investment, and increase the money supply to boost economic activity.

In addition, Keynes emphasized the importance of maintaining full employment through government intervention and policies aimed at reducing inequality. He believed that a more equal distribution of wealth would lead to greater consumer demand and economic growth.
